 section 8.        .

I, 2, 9. daksham dadhate apasam (or  section 2).

I, 6, 10. indram maho va ragasah.

I, 27, 6; 30, 21; 41, 9; 90, 5; III, 24, 5; V, 19, 2; 70, 1; 70, 4; 82, 8; VIII, 2, 27; 2, 31; 16, 9; 55, 4; 67, 19; 81, 5; 81, 8; IX, 47, 2.

But although with regard to the Gayatra, and I <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> add, the Anushtubha padas, the evidence as to the variety of their vrittas is such that it can hardly be resisted, a <span class="t0 t3 t7 t11 t12 t18 t24 t25 t28 hoverable">much</span> more determined stand has been <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">made</span> in defence of the vritta of the Traishtubha and Gagata padas. Here Professor Kuhn and those who follow him maintain that the rule is absolute, that the former <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">must</span> <span class="t0 t4 t10 t12 t13 t20 hoverable">end</span> in      , the latter in        , and that the eighth syllable, immediately preceding these syllables, ought, if possible, to be long. Nor can I deny that Professor Kuhn has <span class="t14 t15 t17 t21 t27 t29 hoverable">brought</span> forward powerful arguments in support of his theory, and that his emendations of the Vedic <span class="t1 t2 t6 t10 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t19 t23 t26 t29 hoverable">text</span> recommend themselves by their <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> ingenuity and simplicity. If his theory <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> be carried out, I should readily admit that we should gain something. We should have throughout the Veda a perfectly uniform metre, and wherever we <span class="t0 t16 t19 t24 hoverable">found</span> any violation of it, we should be justified in resorting to conjectural criticism.

The only question is at what price this strict uniformity can be obtained. If, for instance, in <span class="t0 t2 t3 t6 t7 t10 t13 t14 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">order</span> to have the regular vrittas at the <span class="t0 t4 t10 t12 t13 t20 hoverable">end</span> of Traishtubha and Gagata lines, we were obliged to repeal all rules of prosody, to allow almost <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">every</span> short vowel to be used as long, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t5 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">every</span> <span class="t3 t7 t9 t17 t23 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">long</span> vowel to be used as short, whether <span class="t3 t7 t9 t17 t23 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">long</span> by <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> or by position, we should have gained very little, we

[p. cvii]

should have robbed Peter to pay Paul, we should have removed no difficulty, but only ignored the causes which created it. Now, if we examine the process by which Professor Kuhn establishes the regularity of the vrittas or final syllables of Traishtubha and Gagata padas, we find, in addition to the rules laid down before, and in which he is supported, as we saw, to a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">great</span> extent by the Pratisakhya and Panini, viz. the anceps <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">nature</span> of e and o, and of a <span class="t3 t7 t9 t17 t23 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">long</span> final vowel before a vowel, the following exceptions or metrical licences, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">without</span> which that metrical uniformity at which he aims, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">could</span> not be obtained:

1. The vowel o in the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">body</span> of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> is to be treated as optionally short:

II, 39, 3. prati vastor usra (see Trisht.  section 5).

Here the o of vastoh is supposed to be short, although it is the Guna of u, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> very <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t10 t13 t23 hoverable">different</span> from the final e of sarve or aste, or the final o of sarvo for sarvas or mano for manas [*a]. It should be remarked that in Greek, too, the final diphthongs corresponding to the e of sarve and aste are treated as short, as <span class="t0 t2 t4 t8 t20 t26 hoverable">far</span> as the accent is concerned. Hence apoikoi, tuptetai, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> gnumai, nom. plur. In Latin, too, the <span class="t20 hoverable">old</span> terminations of the nom. sing. o and u, instead of the later us, are short. (Neue, Formenlehre,  section 23 seq.)

VI, 51, 15. gopa ama.

Here the o of gopa is treated as short, in <span class="t0 t2 t3 t6 t7 t10 t13 t14 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">order</span> to get         instead of        , which is perfectly legitimate at the <span class="t0 t4 t10 t12 t13 t20 hoverable">end</span> of an Ushnih.

2. The <span class="t3 t7 t9 t17 t23 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">long</span> i and u are treated as short, not only before vowels, which is legitimate, but <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">also</span> before consonants.

VII, 62, 4. dyavabhumi adite trasitham nah (see Trisht.  section 5).

The forms isiya and rasiya in VII, 32, 18, occur at the <span class="t0 t4 t10 t12 t13 t20 hoverable">end</span> of octosyllabic or Gayatra padas, and are <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span>

[p. cviii]

perfectly legitimate, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">yet</span> Professor Kuhn <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">would</span> change them too, into isiya and rasiya. In VII, 28, 4, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> mayi is treated as mayi (see Trisht.  section 5); and in VII, 68, 1, vitam as vitam. If, in explanation of this shortening of vitam, vihi is quoted, which is identified with vihi, this can hardly be considered as an argument, for vihi occurs where no short syllable is required, IV, 48, 1; II, 26, 2; and where, therefore, the shortening of the vowel <span class="t0 t2 t3 t4 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t13 t14 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t24 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">cannot</span> be attributed to metrical reasons.

3. Final m followed by an initial consonant is allowed to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> no position, and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> in the middle of a <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t19 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">word</span> a nasal followed by a liquid is supposed to <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> positio debilis. Several of the instances, however, <span class="t0 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t12 t13 t15 t18 t21 t23 t24 t25 t27 t29 hoverable">given</span> in support, are from Gayatra padas, where Professor Kuhn, in some of his later articles, has himself allowed greater latitude; <span class="t3 t10 t23 hoverable">others</span> admit of <span class="t2 t3 t4 t6 t10 t13 t23 hoverable">different</span> scanning, as for instance,

I, 117, 8. mahah kshonasya asvina kanvaya.

Here, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">even</span> if we considered the dispondeus as illegitimate, we <span class="t1 t2 t7 t8 t9 t11 t13 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t23 t24 t26 t27 t28 hoverable">might</span> scan kanv*aya, for this scanning occurs in other places, while to treat the <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">first</span> a as short before nv seems tantamount to surrendering all rules of prosody.

4. Final n before semivowels, mutes, and double n before vowels <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> no position [*a]. Ex. III, 49, I. yasmin visva (Trisht.  section 5);. I, 174, 5. yasmin kakan; I, 186, 4. sasmin(n) udhan [*b].

5. Final Visarga before sibilants makes no position [*c]. Ex. IV, 21, 10. satyah samrat (Trisht.  section 5). <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">Even</span> in I, 63, 4.

[p. cix]

[paragraph continues] kodih sakha (probably a Gagata), and V, 82, 4. savih saubhagam (a Gay.  section 7), the <span class="t3 t7 t9 t17 t23 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">long</span> i is treated as short, and the short a of sakha is lengthened, because an aspirate follows.

6. S before mutes makes no position. Ex. VI, 66, II. ugra aspridhran (Trisht.  section 3).

7. S before k makes no position. Ex. visvaskandrah, &c.

8. Mutes before s <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> no position. Ex. rakshas, <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t28 t29 hoverable">according</span> to Professor Kuhn, in the seventh Mandala only, but <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">see</span> I, 12, 5; kutsa, &c.

9. Mutes before r or v <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> no position. Ex. susipra, dirghasrut.

10. Sibilants before y <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">make</span> no position. Ex. dasyun.

11. R followed by mutes or sibilants makes no position. Ex. ayur givase, khardih, varshishtham.

12. <span class="t0 t1 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t29 hoverable">Words</span> <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">like</span> smaddishtin, &c. retain their vowel short before <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">two</span> following consonants.

We now proceed to consider a number of prosodial rules which Professor Kuhn proposes to repeal in <span class="t0 t2 t3 t6 t7 t10 t13 t14 t17 t20 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">order</span> to have a <span class="t3 t7 t9 t17 t23 t25 t26 t27 hoverable">long</span> syllable where the MSS. supply a short:

1. The vowel ri is to be pronounced as long, or rather as ar. Ex. I, 12, 9. tasmai pavaka mrilaya is to be read mardaya; V, 33, 10. samvaranasya risheh is to be read arsheh. But why not samvaranasy  ri*sheh (i. e. siarsheh)?

2. The a privativum <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be lengthened. Ex. agarah, amritah.

3. Short vowels before liquids <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be long. Ex. narah, taruta, tarati, marutam, harivah, arushi, dadhur iha, suvita (p. 471).

4. Short vowels before nasals <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be lengthened. Ex. ganan, sanitar, tanuh, upa nah.

5. Short vowels before the ma of the superlative <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be lengthened. Ex. nritama.

6. The short a in the roots sam and yam, and in am (the termination of the accusative) <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be lengthened.

[p. cx]

7. The group ava is to be pronounced aua. Ex. avase becomes auase; savita becomes sauita; nava becomes naua.

8. The group aya is to be changed into aia or ea. Ex. nayasi becomes naiasi.

9. The group va is to be changed into ua, and this ua to be treated as a kind of diphthong and <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">therefore</span> long. Ex. kanvatamah becomes kanua*tamah; varunah becomes ua*runah.

10. The short vowel in the reduplicated syllable of perfects is to be lengthened. Ex. tatanah, dadhire.

11. Short vowels before all aspirates <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be lengthened. Ex. rathah becomes rathah; sakha becomes sakha.

12. Short vowels before h and all sibilants <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be lengthened. Ex. mahini becomes mahini; usigam becomes usigam; rishate becomes rishate; dasat becomes dasat.

13. The short vowel before t <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be lengthened. Ex. vagavatah becomes vagavatah; atithih becomes atithih.

14. The short vowel before d <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be lengthened. Ex. udaram becomes udaram; ud ava becomes ud ava.

15. The short vowel before p <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be lengthened. Ex. apam becomes apam; tapushim becomes tapushim ; grihapatim becomes grihapatim.

16. The short vowel before g and g <span class="t0 t1 t2 t3 t4 t5 t6 t7 t8 t9 t10 t11 t12 t13 t14 t15 t16 t17 t18 t19 t20 t21 t22 t23 t24 t25 t26 t27 t28 t29 hoverable">may</span> be lengthened. Ex. sanushag asat becomes sanushag asat; yunagan becomes yunagan.
